en.value: Knowing what to say in a bar / restaurant, giving a phone number - "Can" and "could" for polite requests
Read and listen to the expression.
Select the words in the correct order.
Could we have the menu, please?
You can ask this question to a waiter when you are ready to order food.
This question is asked by a waiter.
Can I book a table for two?
Read and listen to the expression and key phrase.
Do you have a table for two?
Can I have the bill, please?
We can use "Can / Could I have..?" to ask for anything. Have a look at the examples below.
Can we have the wine list, please?
Can we have a table by the window?
Can I have a jug of water, please?
Select the phrase you hear in the audio.
Can I book a table, please?
Can I have the menu, please?
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Patrick and Helen are going out for dinner.
Hi, how can I help you?
[k]Sure.[/k] Let me have a look. Is here ok?
[k]Can we have[/k] a table by the window?
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Can I [k]book[/k] a [k]table[/k] for two, please?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Can we have a [k]table[/k] by the window?
What do you say at the end of a meal when you are ready to pay?
Can I have the bill, please?
In this unit we will look at the words "can", "could" and "may". We use these words when we ask for something.
Could we have a jug of water, please?
Listen to the audio. How does Paulina ask the waiter for the bill?
We use "can", "could" and "may" when we ask for something.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Can I book a table for four, please?
Could I have some water please?
"Could", "can" and "may" remain the same with all personal pronouns.
We use a different form of “can” with “he/she”.
Neither "can", "could" nor "may" change to match the personal pronoun.
When we are making requests, “may” relates to permission, while “could” and "can" relate to possibility. However, in most spoken contexts, you can use all three.
George is in a job interview. Which word does he use?
"Could I have..." is considered to be more polite than "Can I have...".
When we make requests, we always put “can”, “could”, or “may” at the beginning.
Could they have a table by the window?
[k]Can I[/k] book a table for four, please?
Select the word you hear in the dialogue.
[k]Could[/k] we have the wine list, please?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
[k]Could I[/k] book a table for four, please?
[k]Can[/k] we have a jug of water, please?
[k]Could we have[/k] a jug of water, please?
